ol.li: Charging or refueling of mobile equipment must be performed by a competent person and in an area designated for that purpose.
Applicable safety equipment must be worn, such as seat belts, when operating forklifts and wheel/steer loaders as well as body harnesses with tie-offs when operating boom and scissor type manlifts.
Operators must not use personal mobile/handheld communication devices whilst operating mobile equipment.
Operators shall report all hazards, near misses, and incidents regardless of fault or severity.
Operators must be aware of overhead clearance and overhead objects such as ceilings, cable trays, pipe work, supporting beams, electrical cabling, lights, and fire suppression systems.
Passengers are not to ride the mobile equipment at any time, unless the equipment is designed to carry more than one person.

Mobile equipment must be clearly visible and audible by persons on foot. Operators must alert employees in the area especially when entering or exiting a building, turning, or reversing by means of reverse alarm, horn, headlights, and flashing beacons.
Always travel with platforms lowered, or so that a load may not obstruct the view from the operatorâ€™s seat.
Site speed limits must be adhered to at all times.
Mobile equipment must not be left unattended by the operator without engaging the parking brake, lowering the load, and shutting off the engine and removing the key.
All mobile equipment cabs must be fitted with suitable protection to protect drivers from falling objects and materials.
Operators of mobile equipment must always give priority to pedestrians and stop at crossings, respecting the Space property at all times.
Operators must always look in the direction of travel when driving mobile equipment (e.g. if reversing, operators must look over their shoulder).

Operators must not drive whilst taking a course of medication that could impair their judgement. Operators must inform their direct supervisor of any medication they have been prescribed so an assessment can be conducted.
